title: Newton's Laws of Motion
introduction: Sir Isaac Newton's three laws of motion describe the relationship between a body and the forces acting upon it, and its motion in response to those forces.

sections.title: First Law (Law of Inertia)
sections.content: An object at rest stays at rest, and an object in motion stays in motion with the same speed and in the same direction unless acted upon by an unbalanced force.
sections.example: A book lying on a table remains at rest until a force (like your hand) moves it.

sections.title: Second Law (F=ma)
sections.content: The acceleration of an object depends on the mass of the object and the amount of force applied.
sections.example: Pushing a shopping cart requires more force if it's filled with groceries compared to when it's empty.

sections.title: Third Law (Action-Reaction)
sections.content: For every action, there is an equal and opposite reaction.
sections.example: When a bird flies, it pushes air downward (action) and the air pushes the bird upward (reaction).

quizQuestions.question: What happens to an object in motion if no external forces act on it?
options: It continues with the same speed and direction

quizQuestions.question: Newton's Second Law is represented by which equation?
options: Both B and C are correct

quizQuestions.question: When you push against a wall, why doesn't it move?
options: The wall exerts an equal and opposite force back on you
